author: Scarlet Howes
title: Straight As student, 18, dies from asthma attack after running to catch tram
text:
News Straight As student, 18, dies from asthma attack after running to catch tram Lucy Goldstone's family began a campaign named ''Restart a Heart for Lucy'' to get defibrillators installed on all public transport Share Tragic Lucy suffered a cardiac arrest and died (Photo: Cavendish Press) Share Get   
A student who was due to get straight A grades in her exams died from a severe asthma attack as she ran to catch a tram. 
A Level student Lucy Goldstone, 18, was on her way home with friends following a night out when they spotted the vehicle. 
The group ran up three flights of stairs and managed to get on board as it was about to pull away from the platform. 
But tragic Lucy - a pupil at the independent Withington Girls School in Manchester and described by her family as 'bright, funny and kind' - collapsed in her seat fighting for breath. 
She suffered a cardiac arrest and died despite efforts from her friends, fellow passengers and paramedics to save her. 
Following an inquest into her death, Lucy's family, from Sale, Greater Manchester began a campaign named ''Restart a Heart for Lucy'' to get defibrillators installed on all public transport to help save the lives of others. Read More The inspiring bond between amputee Marine and girl who lost her legs to meningitis (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
The teen's father James Goldstone, 39, a fund manager said: "We will never know for sure whether a defibrillator would have made a difference for Lucy had it been installed on the tram on which she died. 
''But, without one her chances of surviving a cardiac arrest were negligible. It is hard to understand why, in this safety-conscious age, the installation of defibrillators is not already mandated on the rail carriages that so many people pass through each day. We want to change that in Lucy's memory. 
“She was a talented linguist who was awarded three A grades at A-level and would now be studying French and Spanish at university with unlimited possibilities ahead of her. Her loss is a tragedy with which we, Lucy’s family, are still struggling to come to terms with but which we are determined there should be some positive outcome.” Lucy was a pupil at the independent Withington Girls School in Manchester (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
The Manchester hearing was told Lucy had suffered with mild asthma since the age of ten but had always managed to keep her condition under control using inhalers provided by her GP. 
Mr Goldstone told the inquest: ''She was very good with dealing with it and being sensible. 
"I had never known her to have anything resembling an asthma attack until after her death when I found out that she had a few episodes with asthma. One when she was skiing and she had an asthma attack after climbing a significant way, but this was under control as soon as she took her inhaler. Read More 'Beautiful' mum-of-four 'killed herself jumping in front of train at packed station after sending text message and giving bag to stranger' A Manchester hearing was told Lucy had suffered with mild asthma since the age of ten (Photo: Cavendish Press) 
''I know that two days before her death she had told her friend that she was at the gym but had to leave as she couldn't breathe properly but that only lasted a matter of seconds. She was sending WhatsApp messages expressing concerns about her breathing.'' 
During the hearing Dr Kirstin Ballantyne from Manchester Royal Infirmary said: "I have seen cases where people at train stations have had a heart attack and been bought to back to life with the use of a defibrillator. 
"But in Lucy's case when we got to her heart rhythm was not shockable and there is no way of knowing whether Lucy would have ever been in a stage where her rhythm was shockable." Like us on Facebook
